content.description: Two objects of the same mass travel in the same direction along a horizontal surface. Object <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has a speed of <math alttext="5 meters per second " overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>5</mn><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math> and object <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></math> has a speed of <math alttext="2 meters per seconds " overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>, as shown in the figure. After a period of time, object <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></math> collides with object <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></math>.
content.question: Consider the situation in which object <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has a speed of <math alttext="2 meters per second " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and object <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has a speed of <math alttext="5 meters per second " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> after the collision takes place. After the collision, both objects travel in the same direction. Which of the following predictions must be true about how the momentum <math alttext="vector p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math> of the two-object system and the kinetic energy <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the two-object system change from before the collision to after the collision?

choices.label: <math alttext="vector p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><munder><mrow><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mo>̲</mo></munder></mrow></math><math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mo>̲</mo></munder></mrow></mstyle></math>Remains constantRemains constant

<math alttext="vector p " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mo>̲</mo></munder></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="K " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mo>̲</mo></munder></mrow></mstyle></math>Remains constantDecreases

<math alttext="vector p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mo>̲</mo></munder></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="K " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mo>̲</mo></munder></mrow></mstyle></math>DecreasesRemains constant

content.answer: <math alttext="vector p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><munder><mrow><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mo>̲</mo></munder></mrow></math><math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mo>̲</mo></munder></mrow></mstyle></math>Remains constantRemains constant

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
